First, we need to understand what an Iwato scale is. It is a five-note scale used in traditional Japanese music. It consists of the notes C, Db, F, G, and Ab. 

On the other hand, a twelve-tone technique composition is a method of composition where all twelve notes of the chromatic scale (C, C#, D, D#, E, F, F#, G, G#, A, A#, B) are used equally. In other words, no note is given preference over another. 

So, if we compare the two scales, we can see that the Iwato scale only has five notes, while the twelve-tone technique requires all twelve notes of the chromatic scale to be used. Therefore, it would be impossible to use an Iwato scale for a twelve-tone technique composition. 

Hence, the answer to the question is (A) Yes.

First, an Iwato scale is a five-note scale used in Japanese music. It has a particular set of intervals between the notes, which are not the same as the intervals used in Western music. 

Next, twelve-tone technique is a compositional method developed by Arnold Schoenberg in which all twelve pitches of the chromatic scale are used equally, without preference for any one note or key. 

Since the Iwato scale only has five notes with a specific interval pattern, it would not allow for all twelve pitches of the chromatic scale to be used equally. Therefore, it would be impossible to use an Iwato scale for a twelve-tone technique composition. 

As such, the correct answer is (A) yes, it would be impossible to use an Iwato scale for a twelve-tone technique composition.
